newsitem.title: JAPAN: Female dominates Tokyo Zoo monkey business.
newsitem.headline: Female dominates Tokyo Zoo monkey business.

text.p: Crowds are surging into Tokyo's main zoo to see female power at work.
The reason for the excitement is "Aizuhomare", a female monkey who has broken a 27-year-long male tradition by taking over leadership of the zoo's band of 37 monkeys.
Ueno Zoo curator Osamu Ishida told Reuters that in the zoo's 65-year history, there had only been three times when a female became leader of its band of Japanese macaque monkeys.
Each time female rule lasted for less than a year.
"It's very rare in a zoo and in the wild for a female monkey to be on top of the heap," Ishida said.

The 20-year-old Aizuhomare, named after a famed Japanese sake or rice wine, fought off challenges by half a dozen younger males to reach the point where she automatically now gets first choice of titbits sightseers throw to the monkeys and grooming privileges from other monkeys.
The fight for leadership was set off earlier this year after the death of Satoimo, a male who had ruled the band.
Ishida said in the final leadership battle, Aizuhomare "swatted" the strongest male just after the pair had mated.
"He never recovered and now Aizuhomare rules," he said.
Since publicising the rise of monkey business feminism, the simians have become the zoo's most popular sight.
Among human onlookers, a battle of the sexes has broken out about whether Aizuhomare's rise is a sign of female power or male weakness.
"Monkeys are our ancestors so if these females here are getting stronger, maybe it also means that Japanese women are getting stronger," mused 23-year-old Kunion Kawasaki.
"I'm not surprised," sniffed Mami Kaneko, 25. "Most Japanese men are very weak now."
